title: One in five adults in Wales 'not online' |
text:
It's estimated that around one in five adults in Wales are still not online, according to Digital Communities Wales.
It says there are worries that they're missing out on opportunities to save money, look for work and learn new skills.
Blaenau Gwent has the highest percentage of adults who are not online, compared to the lowest in Cardiff.
The Welsh Government run project Digital Communities Wales is urging people who are comfortable using computers and mobile devices to come forward and help others around them who may need support to get online.
Being online can open doors to fantastic new opportunities - from accessing information, to searching for work, and learning new skills.
Through supporting people to develop their confidence and become more competent online, volunteers can help people discover the life-changing potential of the internet.
This campaign is particularly timely as this week is Get Online Week - I encourage anybody who can share their digital skills with others to get involved!
